What if you're too ignorant to realize that you're too ignorant...

About Me:

  • I graduated university in 2013 with a degree in Economics & Statistics.
  • Worked in personal finance for 4 years.
  • Quit my job in 2017 to travel the world.
  • Came back to California in Dec 2019 to attend a software engineering bootcamp.
  • Finished the program in July 2020; currently work as a support engineer for a fintech company (Affirm).

Now, let's talk about cognitive biases!
  • Begin
Confirmation Bias

Explanation:

"Survivorship bias is a common logical error that distorts our understanding of the world. It happens when we assume that success tells the whole story and when we don’t adequately consider past failures."

Examples:

  • WWII Planes
  • Arguing with your parents about dropping out of university
  • ESP and the test of telepathy
  • People online posting dogecoin gains
Selection Bias

Explanation:

"Survivorship bias is a common logical error that distorts our understanding of the world. It happens when we assume that success tells the whole story and when we don’t adequately consider past failures."

Examples:

  • WWII Planes
  • Arguing with your parents about dropping out of university
  • ESP and the test of telepathy
  • People online posting dogecoin gains
Survivorship Bias

Explanation:

"Survivorship bias is a common logical error that distorts our understanding of the world. It happens when we assume that success tells the whole story and when we don’t adequately consider past failures."

Examples:

  • WWII Planes
  • Arguing with your parents about dropping out of university
  • ESP and the test of telepathy
  • People online posting dogecoin gains
Recency Bias

Explanation:

Recency bias is a cognitive bias that favors recent events over historic ones. A memory bias, recency bias gives "greater importance to the most recent event"

Examples:

  • Stock investors remember the most recent market trends
  • The endings of advertisements are generally upbeat/funny
  • While studying, the last step is to "review old material"
  • The adage "Don't go to bed angry"
Dunning-Kruger Effect

Explanation:

The Dunning-Kruger effect is a cognitive bias in which people wrongly overestimate their knowledge or ability in a specific area. This tends to occur because a lack of self-awareness prevents them from accurately assessing their own skills.

In short: to be too stupid to realize that you're stupid

Examples:

Sunk Cost Fallacy

Explanation:

The Dunning-Kruger effect is a cognitive bias in which people wrongly overestimate their knowledge or ability in a specific area. This tends to occur because a lack of self-awareness prevents them from accurately assessing their own skills.

In short: to be too stupid to realize that you're stupid
